article:
'Bioelectrical impedance analysis' (BIA) is a commonly used method for
estimating body composition, and in particular body fat. Since the advent of the
first commercially available devices in the mid-1980s the method has become
popular owing to its ease of use, portability of the equipment and its
relatively low cost compared to some of the other methods of body composition
analysis. It is familiar in the consumer market as a simple instrument for
estimating body fat. BIA Downloadable as PDF: [http://www.ake-
nutrition.at/uploads/media/bia1_Kyle_et_al_01.pdf Part 1] [http://www.ake-
nutrition.at/uploads/media/bia2_Kyle_et_al_01.pdf Part 2] actually
determines the electrical impedance, or opposition to the flow of an electric
current through body tissues which can then be used to calculate an estimate of
total body water (TBW). TBW can be used to estimate fat-free body mass and, by
difference with body weight, body fat.
